Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Comparative Analysis of Arizona and Texas Groundwater Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the factors that promote and hinder the effectiveness of different approaches to governing groundwater pumping in the context of rapid urban growth and competing water demands. As cities in the Western U.S. continue to grow and water demands increase, questions regarding the reallocation of already over-allocated water supplies are becoming increasingly critical. Despite some achievements in conservation, policy results have been uneven and often have been unable to bring long-term aquifer declines under control. It therefore is important to evaluate approaches to governing groundwater in order to identify important weaknesses and propose reforms. This research project will compare the more localized groundwater districts and Edwards Aquifer groundwater cap-and-trade system in Texas to the more centralized, permit-based Arizona approach. Paying special attention to the different institutions (systems of working rules) that shape human use of water resources, this doctoral student will investigate how groundwater districts manage groundwater in two major Southwestern metropolises, Phoenix and San Antonio. The three main questions on which this project will focus are: (1) How do the institutional arrangements in centralized and decentralized groundwater governance systems produce differences in the incorporation of new groundwater uses and management of conflicts? (2) How does market-based trading compare to administrative permitting in the reallocation of groundwater from rural to urban users? (3) How important are groundwater districts for controlling aquifer depletion relative to state laws, state administration, and regional political economic factors? Documentary evidence will consist of relevant water rights laws and court cases, regulatory statutes, records of rulemaking by groundwater districts, and media reports on water-related issues and conflicts. Historical water-trading and permitting data will also be collected, and interviews will be conducted with numerous stakeholders. The student will triangulate among these different sets of evidence, comparatively analyzing the planning and decision-making processes, incidence and management of groundwater conflicts, frequency and type of rulemaking, and frequency and amount of rural to urban water reallocation for the districts in the two metro areas.

This project's analysis of the Phoenix and San Antonio cases will help explain failures to alleviate groundwater overdraft and identify laws and policies that might be worth copying or not by other states. By comparing centralized and local groundwater districts, permit-based systems and market-oriented ones, this project will contribute to academic and policy debates about the merits of decentralized governance and the degree of "fit" of different organizational forms for managing common pool water resources. The project also will highlight negative socioeconomic impacts on rural communities that can result from the reallocation of water from rural to urban uses. Findings will be disseminated through scholarly publications as well as through documents developed for stakeholders. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Background

Environmental governance -- broadly understood as a process of decision-making about the use of natural resources involving both governments and civil society -- is a dominant paradigm in studies of human-environment interactions. Ongoing debates in the academic and professional communities center around what the best approaches for governing groundwater resources are in order to achieve long-term environmental sustainability while also satisfying social goals of fairness, inclusion, and adaptability. Because each U.S. state has authority to create its own water policies and regulations, their experiments with governing groundwater can be compared in order to learn from their respective successes and limitations. This study compared two contrasting approaches exemplified by two metro areas – Phoenix, Arizona and San Antonio, Texas – based on key aspects of governance, including organizational form and the use of market-based mechanisms for groundwater allocation.

Academic Outcomes

This study contributes to our empirical knowledge of the emerging trend in the West of local-scale groundwater governance by identifying key limitations in two local San Antonio-area districts experiencing rapid urban growth and increasing groundwater demands, including:

  • Inconsistent regulatory authority
  • Vulnerability to lawsuits
  • Unfunded planning mandates
  • Inadequate funding mechanisms
  • Lack of local participation

Analysis of two management areas in the Phoenix metro region shows that many of these problems have been avoided but localized problems of long-term water table declines still exist.  Overall, the analysis contributes to scholarly debates by arguing against the uncritical adoption of bottom-up governance. Instead, based on the theoretical concept of polycentric governance borrowed from public policy scholars, a governance system with greater amounts of overlap in decision-making bodies at nested administrative levels could address challenges in both Texas and Arizona. Besides deepening debates in geography about the merits of decentralized governance, these findings also have practical relevance. For example, findings from this study could inform the implementation of California’s recently adopted decentralized groundwater management model in order to avoid some of the problems experienced in Texas.

Additionally, analysis of the Texas Edwards Aquifer groundwater trading system adds a fine-grained understanding of how specific physical characteristics of aquifers matter a great deal to the implementation of a cap and trade scheme and should not be overlooked by economists and policy makers. Even in an unusually homogeneous aquifer such as the Edwards, rules must be created to mitigate negative third-party effects on the aquifer and hydrologically-connected surface water bodies. Calls for greater use of market-based groundwater allocation in Arizona, where groundwater markets are demonstrably limited, should take these factors into account.

These and other results have been communicated to academic geography audiences at the Dimensions of Political Ecology conference (2014) at the University of Kentucky and the Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting (2015). Final results will also be presented at the 2016 Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting.

Additionally, a professional contact that was made while conducting fieldwork in Texas led to a paper solicitation, which the co-PI was able to meet using research conducted for this project on Arizona and Texas. The resulting journal article, “Conjunctive groundwater management as a response to socio-ecological disturbances: a comparison of four western U.S. States,” was published in the open access Texas Water Journal...
